# B Equality of Modified Beta Function and Shapley Value Weights 

Lemma 3. We have the following recurrence relationship:

$$
\beta_{n, 0}=\beta_{n, n}=\frac{1}{n+1} \text { and } \beta_{n, m}=\frac{m}{n-(m-1)} \beta_{n, m-1}
$$

Proof. There are two cases.
Case $1(m$ is equal to zero, or $n$ ). We have the following integration.

$$
\beta_{n, 0}=\int_{0}^{1}(1-x)^{n} d x=-\left.\frac{(1-x)^{n+1}}{n+1}\right|_{0} ^{1}=\frac{1}{n+1}
$$

A nearly identical calculation can be used to show $\beta_{n, n}$ is equal to $\frac{1}{n+1}$.
Case $2(0<m<n)$. We have the following partial integration:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\beta_{n, m} & =\int_{0}^{1} x^{m}(1-x)^{n-m} d x \\
& =\left.\frac{x^{m}(1-x)^{n-(m-1)}}{n-(m-1)}\right|_{0} ^{1}-\int_{0}^{1} \frac{-m}{n-(m-1)} x^{m-1}(1-x)^{n-(m-1)} d x \\
& =0+\frac{m}{n-(m-1)} \int_{0}^{1} x^{m-1}(1-x)^{n-(m-1)} d x \\
& =\frac{m}{n-(m-1)} \beta_{n, m-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 6. The beta function $\beta_{n, m}$ is equal to the Shapley weight function $\gamma(n, m)$, with $0 \leq m \leq n$ and $m, n \in \mathbb{N}$.
Proof. The proof is by induction on $m$.
Base case $(m=0)$. According to Case 1 of Lemma 3, we have that $\beta_{n, 0}$ is equal to $\frac{1}{n+1}$, which is equal to $\gamma(n, 0)$.
Inductive step $(m>0)$. Suppose $\beta_{n, k}$ is equal to $\gamma(n, k), k \in \mathbb{N}$, we need to show $\beta_{n, k+1}=\gamma(n, k+1), 0 \leq k<n$. According to Case 2 of Lemma $3, \beta_{n, k+1}$ is equal to $\frac{k+1}{n-k} \beta_{n, k}$. Using the inductive hypothesis, the latter is equivalent to

$$
\frac{k+1}{n-k} \gamma(n, k)=\frac{k+1}{n-k} \cdot \frac{k!(n-k)!}{(n+1)!}
$$

which matches the definition of $\gamma(n, k+1)$.

## C Riemann Sum Samples

Lemma 4. $t_{\ell}^{\prime}(k)$ is in range $\left[t_{\ell}(k), t_{\ell}(k+1)\right]$.
Proof. Recall the definition for $t_{\ell}(k)=\sin ^{2}\left(\pi\left(k / 2^{\ell+1}\right)\right)$. Since $t_{\ell}^{\prime}(k)=t_{\ell+1}(2 k+1)$, we have that,

$$
t_{\ell}^{\prime}(k)=\sin ^{2}\left(\pi \frac{k+1 / 2}{2^{\ell+1}}\right)=t_{\ell}^{\prime}(k+1 / 2)
$$

Since $k \in\left\{0, \ldots, 2^{\ell}-1\right\}, t_{\ell}(x)$ is increasing for $x \in[k, k+1]$ for all $k$. Therefore, since $k+1 / 2 \in[k, k+1]$, the result holds.

# D Complexity and Error Analysis 

D. 1 Error - Step 1. It is important to assess the error and complexity of Step 1 of the Section 5 algorithm.

Definition 9 (Darboux Sums). Darboux sums [23, page 270] takes a partition $P=\left(z_{0}, z_{1}, \ldots, z_{r}\right)$ of an interval $[a, b]$, where $a=z_{0}<z_{1}<\cdots<z_{r}=b$, and a function $f$ which maps $(a, b)$ to $\mathbb{R}$. Each interval $\left[z_{i}, z_{i+1}\right]$ is called a subinterval. Let

$$
\begin{gathered}
M_{i}=\sup _{x \in\left[z_{i}, z_{i+1}\right]} f(x), \quad \text { and } \\
m_{i}=\inf _{x \in\left[z_{i}, z_{i+1}\right]} f(x), \quad i=0, \ldots, r-1
\end{gathered}
$$

The upper Darboux sum and the lower Darboux sum are:

$$
U(f, P)=\sum_{i=0}^{r-1} M_{i}\left(z_{i+1}-z_{i}\right), \quad L(f, P)=\sum_{i=0}^{r-1} m_{i}\left(z_{i+1}-z_{i}\right)
$$

Corollary 2. Given a partition $P=\left(z_{0}, \ldots, z_{r}\right)$ of an interval $[a, b]$ and an integrable function $f:[a, b] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, any Riemann sum (Definition 7) is greater than or equal to the lower Darboux sum and less than or equal to than the upper Darboux sum,

$$
L(f, P) \leq \sum_{i=0}^{r-1} f\left(z_{i}^{\prime}\right)\left(z_{i+1}-z_{i}\right) \leq U(f, P)
$$

where $z_{i}^{\prime} \in\left[z_{i}, z_{i+1}\right]$.
Lemma 5. Given a partition $P=\left(z_{0}, \ldots, z_{r}\right)$ of an interval $[a, b]$ and an integrable function $f:[a, b] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, the integral of $f$ from a to $b$ is greater than the lower Darboux sum and smaller than the upper Darboux sum.

$$
L(f, P) \leq \int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x \leq U(f, P)
$$

Proof. By the Mean Value Theorem [23, page 233], there exists an $p_{i} \in\left[z_{i}, z_{i+1}\right]$, such that,

$$
f\left(p_{i}\right)=\frac{1}{z_{i+1}-z_{i}} \int_{z_{i}}^{z_{i+1}} f(t) d t
$$

Hence, we can create the following Riemann sum (Definition 7),

$$
\sum_{k=0}^{r-1}\left(z_{i+1}-z_{i}\right) f\left(p_{i}\right)=\sum_{k=0}^{r-1} \int_{z_{i}}^{z_{i+1}} f(x) d x=\int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x
$$

Thus, by Corollary 2, the result holds.
Lemma 6. Let $P=\left(z_{0}, \ldots, z_{r}\right)$ be a partition of an interval $[a, b]$ and suppose the function $f:[a, b] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is integrable. Then, the error of a Riemann sum is bounded by the difference of the upper and lower Darboux sums, that is, the difference between the Riemann sum and the integral is bounded by,

$$
\left|\int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x-\sum_{k=0}^{r-1} f\left(z_{k}^{\prime}\right)\left(z_{k+1}-z_{k}\right)\right| \leq U(f, P)-L(f, P)
$$

where $z_{k}^{\prime} \in\left[z_{k}, z_{k+1}\right]$.
Manuscript submitted to ACM TQC

Proof. We must show that the absolute difference between any given Riemann sum and the integral from $a$ to $b$ is less than or equal to the absolute difference between the upper and lower Darboux sums. Without loss of generality, suppose the integral is greater than the Riemann sum. By Lemma 5,

$$
\int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x-\sum_{k=0}^{r-1} f\left(z_{k}^{\prime}\right)\left(z_{k+1}-z_{k}\right) \leq U(f, P)-\sum_{k=0}^{r-1} f\left(z_{k}^{\prime}\right)\left(z_{k+1}-z_{k}\right)
$$

Similarly, by Corollary 2,

$$
U(f, P)-\sum_{k=0}^{r-1} f\left(z_{k}^{\prime}\right)\left(z_{k+1}-z_{k}\right) \leq U(f, P)-L(f, P)
$$

Lemma 6 allows us to bound the error of any Riemann sum approximation for an integral, giving us a sequence of boxes that bound the error for their respective subinterval. A convenient result of our method is that given only a partition; we can guarantee error bounds given any selection of samples.

Corollary 3. Recall the function $b_{n, m}(x)=x^{m}(1-x)^{n-m}$ (Definition 6) and partition $P_{f}=\left(t_{f}(0), \ldots, t_{f}\left(2^{f}\right)\right)$ of $[0,1]$. Lemma 6 implies that the error of a Riemann sum using $b_{n, m}$ and $P_{f}$ is upper bounded by,

$$
\sum_{k=0}^{2^{f}-1} w_{f}(k)\left(M_{k}-m_{k}\right)
$$

$w_{f}(k)$ is defined in Equation (19) and $m_{k}, M_{k}$ are defined in Definition 9.
It is important to find a simple upper bound for the function $w_{f}(k)$ and the difference $M_{k}-m_{k}$.
Lemma 7. $w_{f}(k)$ is upper bounded by a function that depends solely on $f$ :

$$
w_{f}(k) \leq \frac{\pi}{2^{f+1}}
$$

Proof. Recall Equation (19), $w_{f}(k)=\sin ^{2}(a+b)-\sin ^{2}(a)$, where $a=\pi k / 2^{f+1}, b=\pi / 2^{f+1}$. Then, we have,

$$
w_{f}(k)=[\sin (a+b)+\sin (a)][\sin (a+b)-\sin (a)]
$$

Proceeding with common trigonometric identities yields,

$$
w_{f}(k)=\left[2 \sin \frac{b}{2} \cos \frac{b}{2}\right]\left[2 \sin \frac{2 a+b}{2} \cos \frac{2 a+b}{2}\right]
$$

which is equal to,

$$
\sin (b) \sin (2 a+b)
$$

Since $0 \leq \sin (2 a+b) \leq 1$, and $\sin x \leq x$ when $x$ is non-negative, the result holds.

Remark 2. It is helpful to note that $b_{n, m}(x)=b_{n, n-m}(1-x)$.
Lemma 8. Let $n \in \mathbb{N}$, and suppose $m \in\{1, \cdots, n-1\}$, then the derivative of $b_{n, m}(x)$ is,

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d} b_{n, m}(x)}{\mathrm{d} x}=\frac{(m-n x) b_{n, m}(x)}{x(1-x)}
$$

Proof. Recall the definition of $b_{n, m}(x)=x^{m}(1-x)^{n-m}$, then by the product rule,

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d} b_{n, m}(x)}{\mathrm{d} x}=m x^{m-1}(1-x)^{n-m}-(n-m) x^{m}(1-x)^{n-m-1}
$$

Pulling out the common terms yields,

$$
x^{m-1}(1-x)^{n-m-1}(m(1-x)-(n-m) x)
$$

Collecting like terms and rearranging gives,

$$
\frac{(m-n x)\left(x^{m}(1-x)^{n-m}\right)}{x(1-x)}
$$

Lemma 9. For $m=0, n$, the derivatives of $b_{n, m}$ are,

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d} b_{n, 0}(x)}{\mathrm{d} x}=n(1-x)^{n-1} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{\mathrm{d} b_{n, n}(x)}{\mathrm{d} x}=n x^{n-1}
$$

respectively.
Lemma 10. Let $n \in \mathbb{N}$ and $m \in\{0, \cdots, n\}$, then for all $x$ in $[0,1]$,

$$
b_{n, m}(x) \leq b_{n, m}(m / n)
$$

Proof. Suppose $m=n$, then $b_{n, m}(x)=x^{n}$. Clearly, $x^{n}$ is increasing on the interval $[0,1]$, thus $b_{n, m}$ is maximized at $x=1=m / n$. By Remark 2, if $m=0$, the max of $b_{n, m}$ is also 1 and this occurs at $x=0=m / n$.

Finally, if $1 \leq m \leq n-1$, then $b_{n, m}(0)=b_{n, m}(1)=0$. Note that $b_{n, m}(x)$ is strictly positive for $x \in(0,1)$, and there is only one critical point on that interval. Thus, the maximum must be the critical point $x$ between $(0,1)$. By Lemma 8 , this critical point satisfies $m-n x=0$. Therefore, $b_{n, m}(x)$ is maximized when $x=m / n$.

Corollary 4. If $x<m / n$, then $b_{n, m}(x)$ is increasing at $x$,

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d} b_{n, m}(x)}{\mathrm{d} x}>0
$$

and if $x>m / n$, then $b_{n, m}(x)$ is decreasing at $x$,

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d} b_{n, m}(x)}{\mathrm{d} x}<0
$$

Definition 10 (Notation). We define the function $\gamma_{\ell}(n, m)$ as the following Riemann sum approximation for $\gamma(n, m)$,

$$
\gamma_{\ell}(n, m)=\sum_{k=0}^{2^{p}-1} w_{\ell}(k) \cdot b_{n, m}\left(t_{\ell}^{\prime}(k)\right)
$$

Let $u_{\ell}(n, m)$ be the signed difference between $\gamma_{\ell}(n, m)$ and $\gamma(n, m)$,

$$
u_{\ell}(n, m)=\gamma_{\ell}(n, m)-\gamma(n, m)
$$

Lemma 11. The estimation $\gamma_{\ell}(n, m)$ has an absolute error upper bounded by,

$$
\left|u_{\ell}(n, m)\right| \leq \frac{\pi}{2^{p}} b_{n, m}(m / n)
$$

Manuscript submitted to ACM TQC

Proof. Note, for the sake of space, we omit the cases where $m=0$ and $m=1$, though they do follow the same bound. Suppose $m \in\{1, \ldots, n-1\}$. By Corollary 3, we have,

$$
\left|u_{\ell}(n, m)\right| \leq \sum_{k=0}^{2^{d}-1} w_{\ell}(k)\left(M_{k}-m_{k}\right)
$$

Applying Lemma 7 shows this is less than or equal to,

$$
\frac{\pi}{2^{d+1}} \sum_{k=0}^{2^{d}-1} M_{k}-m_{k}
$$

Define $j_{k}, j_{k}$ to be in interval $\left[t_{\ell}(k), t_{\ell}(k+1)\right]$ such that $m_{k}=b_{n, m}\left(j_{k}\right), M_{k}=b_{n, m}\left(j_{k}\right)$. Then,

$$
\frac{\pi}{2^{d+1}} \sum_{k=0}^{2^{d}-1} M_{k}-m_{k}=\frac{\pi}{2^{d+1}} \sum_{k=0}^{2^{d}-1} b_{n, m}\left(j_{k}\right)-b_{n, m}\left(j_{k}\right)
$$

For any $k$ such that $t_{\ell}(k+1) \leq m / n$, by Corollary $4, x \in\left(t_{\ell}(k), t_{\ell}(k+1)\right)$ implies that $\frac{d}{d x} b_{n, m}(x)$ is strictly positive. Thus, the leftmost part of the subinterval $\left[t_{\ell}(k), t_{\ell}(k+1)\right]$ is the minimum with respect to $b_{n, m}(x)$ and the rightmost part is the maximum, so,

$$
b_{n, m}\left(j_{k}\right)-b_{n, m}\left(j_{k}\right)=b_{n, m}\left(t_{\ell}(k+1)\right)-b_{n, m}\left(t_{\ell}(k)\right)
$$

Similarly, for $k$ such that $t_{\ell}(k) \geq m / n$, by Corollary $4, x \in\left(t_{\ell}(k), t_{\ell}(k+1)\right)$ implies $\frac{d}{d x} b_{n, m}(x)$ is strictly negative, so,

$$
b_{n, m}\left(j_{k}\right)-b_{n, m}\left(j_{k}\right)=-\left[b_{n, m}\left(t_{\ell}(k+1)\right)-b_{n, m}\left(t_{\ell}(k)\right)\right]
$$

If for some $k, t_{\ell}(k)$ is equal to $m / n$, then we have described each interval. Supposing that for all $k, t_{\ell}(k) \neq m / n$, there exists one other subinterval $\left[t_{\ell}(s), t_{\ell}(s+1)\right]$ that is non-monotonic. Its absolute error is bounded by,

$$
b_{n, m}\left(j_{s}\right)-b_{n, m}\left(j_{s}\right)=\max _{r \in\{0,1\}} b_{n, m}(m / n)-b_{n, m}\left(t_{\ell}(s+r)\right)
$$

Thus, we have the following upper bound for the absolute error,

$$
\frac{\pi}{2^{d+1}}\left(\sum_{k=0}^{s-1}\left(M_{k}-m_{k}\right)+\left(M_{s}-m_{s}\right)+\sum_{k=s+1}^{2^{d}-1}\left(M_{k}-m_{k}\right)\right)
$$

where we take $s=0$ when there is no non-monotonic sub-interval. Plugging in Equations (26), 27, and 28, yields the absolute error upper bound of,

$$
\max _{r \in\{0,1\}} \frac{\pi}{2^{d+1}}\left\{\left(\sum_{k=0}^{s-1} b_{n, m}\left(t_{\ell}(k+1)\right)-b_{n, m}\left(t_{\ell}(k)\right)\right)+\left[b_{n, m}(m / n)-b_{n, m}\left(t_{\ell}(s+r)\right)\right]-\left(\sum_{k=s+1}^{2^{d}-1} b_{n, m}\left(t_{\ell}(k+1)\right)-b_{n, m}\left(t_{\ell}(k)\right)\right)\right\}
$$

We can telescope both series into,

$$
\max _{r \in\{0,1\}} \frac{\pi}{2^{d+1}}\left\{\left(b_{n, m}\left(t_{\ell}(s)\right)-b_{n, m}(0)\right)+\left(b_{n, m}(m / n)-b_{n, m}\left(t_{\ell}(s+r)\right)\right)-\left(b_{n, m}\left(t_{\ell}\left(2^{d}\right)\right)-b_{n, m}\left(t_{\ell}(s+1)\right)\right)\right\}
$$

Note that $b_{n, m}(0)=b_{n, m}\left(2^{d}\right)=0$, and that $-b_{n, m}\left(t_{\ell}(s+r)\right)$ cancel out either $b_{n, m}(s)$ or $b_{n, m}(s+1)$. The above equation is upper bounded by,

$$
\max _{r \in\{0,1\}} \frac{\pi}{2^{d+1}}\left\{b_{n, m}(m / n)+b_{n, m}\left(t_{\ell}(s+r)\right)\right\}
$$

Thus, Lemma 10 implies the result.

Lemma 12. Let $n$ be greater or equal to two and suppose $m$ is in $\{1, \ldots, n-1\}$, we have the following inequality,

$$
\binom{n}{m} \cdot b_{n, m}(m / n)<\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{n}{m(n-m)}}
$$

Proof. First note that $b_{n, m}(m / n)$ can be rewritten as,

$$
\frac{m^{m}(n-m)^{n-m}}{n^{n}}
$$

Additionally, by a slightly improved version of Stirling's approximation [45], for $k$ greater than or equal to one,

$$
\sqrt{2 \pi k}\left(\frac{k}{e}\right)^{k} e^{\frac{1}{12 k+1}}<k!<\sqrt{2 \pi k}\left(\frac{k}{e}\right)^{k} e^{\frac{1}{12 k}}
$$

It follows directly from Equation (30), and the inequality $(12 n)^{-1}-(12 m+1)^{-1}-(12(n-m)+1)^{-1}<0$, that,

$$
\binom{n}{m}=\frac{n!}{m!(n-m)!}<\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{n}{m(n-m)}} \cdot \frac{n^{n}}{m^{m}(n-m)^{n-m}}
$$

Multiplying the Equations (29) and (31) yields the result.

Definition 11. We write a Shapley value estimation using $\gamma_{T}$ as,

$$
\Phi_{T}(i)=\sum_{S \subseteq F \backslash\{i\}} \gamma_{T}(\{S\},\{F \backslash\{i\}\}) \cdot(V(S \cup\{i\})-V(S))
$$

Lemma 13. The following inequality holds for $n$ greater or equal to three,

$$
\sum_{m=1}^{n-1}\binom{n}{m} b_{n, m}(m / n) \leq \sqrt{\frac{\pi n}{2}}
$$

Proof. The bound for odd $n$ is similar to finding a bound for an even $n$. We proceed assuming $n$ is equal to $2 k+1$ where $k \in \mathbb{N}$. By Lemma 12, we immediately get the upper bound,

$$
\sqrt{\frac{n}{2 \pi}} \sum_{m=1}^{2 k} \frac{1}{\sqrt{m(n-m)}}
$$

This can be rewritten as,

$$
\sqrt{\frac{n}{2 \pi}}\left[\left(\sum_{m=1}^{k-1} \frac{1}{\sqrt{m(n-m)}}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{k(n-k)}}\right)+\left(\sum_{m=k+1}^{2 k} \frac{1}{\sqrt{m(n-m)}}\right)\right]
$$

The expansions of the summations are equal. We have the upper bound,

$$
\sqrt{\frac{2 n}{\pi}}\left(\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{k(n-k)}}+\sum_{m=1}^{k-1} \frac{1}{\sqrt{m(n-m)}}\right)
$$

Next, note that $1 / \sqrt{m(2 k-m)}$ is a decreasing function on the interval $(0, n / 2]$. So,

$$
\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{k(n-k)}}+\sum_{m=1}^{k} \frac{1}{\sqrt{m(2 k-m)}}
$$

can be interpreted as the lower Darboux sum of function $(m(n-m))^{-1 / 2}$, on the interval $(0, k]$, using partition $P=(0,1, \ldots, k-1, k, k+1 / 2)$.
Manuscript submitted to ACM TQC

By Lemma 5, this implies Equation (33) is upper bounded by,

$$
\int_{0}^{n / 2} \frac{1}{\sqrt{x(n-x)}} d x
$$

By converting the product $x(n-x)$ to vertex form, performing a substitution, and finally performing a trigonometric substitution, we find the definite integral equals $\pi / 2$. Combining this with Equation (32) shows the result.

Theorem 7. If $n$ is greater or equal to two, assuming Steps 2 and 3 introduce no error, the Shapley value estimation has the following upper bound on absolute error,

$$
\left|\Phi_{\ell}(i)-\Phi(i)\right| \leq \frac{\left(V_{\max }-V_{\min }\right) \sqrt{n}}{2^{\ell-3}}
$$

Proof. By Definitions 10 and 11, the $\ell$ th Shapley value approximation can be written as,

$$
\Phi_{\ell}(i)=\sum_{S \subseteq F \backslash\{i\}}[\gamma(|S|,|F \backslash\{i\}|)+u_{\ell}(|S|,|F \backslash\{i\}|) \mid \cdot[V(S \cup\{i\})-V(S)]
$$

Pulling the terms apart and applying the standard equation for Shapley values give,

$$
\Phi_{\ell}(i)=\Phi(i)+\sum_{S \subseteq F \backslash\{i\}} u_{\ell}(|S|,|F \backslash\{i\}|) \cdot(V(S \cup\{i\})-V(S))
$$

Thus, the Shapley estimation absolute error is equal to,

$$
\left|\Phi_{\ell}(i)-\Phi(i)\right|=\left|\sum_{S \subseteq F \backslash\{i\}} u_{\ell}(|S|,|F \backslash\{i\}|) \cdot(V(S \cup\{i\})-V(S))\right|
$$

which is thus upper bounded by,

$$
\sum_{S \subseteq F \backslash\{i\}}\left|u_{\ell}(|S|,|F \backslash\{i\}|) \mid \cdot|(V(S \cup\{i\})-V(S))\right|
$$

Recall $V_{\max }$ and $V_{\min }$, defined in Equations (6) and (7). This gives a new upper bounds for $\left|\Phi_{\ell}(i)-\Phi(i)\right|$,

$$
\left(V_{\max }-V_{\min }\right) \cdot \sum_{S \subseteq F \backslash\{i\}}\left|u_{\ell}(|S|,|F \backslash\{i\}|)\right|
$$

By Lemma 11 and a reinterpretation of the sum, we have the upper bound,

$$
\frac{\pi\left(V_{\max }-V_{\min }\right)}{2^{\ell}} \cdot \sum_{m=0}^{n}\binom{n}{m} b_{n, m}(m / n)
$$

For $n$ equal to two, the sum is less than $\left(V_{\max }-V_{\min }\right) / 2^{\ell-3}$. Hence, the result holds. Assuming $n$ greater or equal to three, by Lemma 13, the above is less than,

$$
\frac{\pi\left(V_{\max }-V_{\min }\right)}{2^{\ell}}\left(\sqrt{\frac{\pi n}{2}}+\binom{n}{0} 1+\binom{n}{n}\right)=\frac{\pi\left(V_{\max }-V_{\min }\right)}{2^{\ell}}\left(\sqrt{\frac{\pi n}{2}}+2\right)
$$

Hence, the result holds.
D. 2 Error - Step 2. Suppose $U_{V}^{ \pm}$is an imperfect implementation of $\hat{V}^{ \pm}$, such that,

$$
\delta_{h}^{ \pm}=\left\langle V^{ \pm}(h) \mid 1\right\rangle\left\langle 1 \mid V^{ \pm}(h)\right\rangle-\hat{V}^{ \pm}(h), \quad \delta_{h}=\delta_{h}^{+}-\delta_{h}^{-}
$$

where $\left|V^{*}(h)\right\rangle=U_{V}^{*}(h)|0\rangle$ (Equation (14)). We also define,

$$
\delta_{\max } \geq \max _{h \in\left\{0, \ldots, 2^{n}-1\right\}}\left|\delta_{h}\right|
$$

In plain language, $\delta_{h}$ is the error of our quantum implementation in how much player $i$ would contribute to the coalition represented by the binary string $h$. Additionally, $\delta_{\max }$ upper bounds the error of $\delta_{h}$.

With these definitions in mind, let us see how the error in our quantum implementation propagates. Let us first recall our state after Step 2 (Section 5).

$$
\operatorname{tr}_{\mathrm{Pt}, \mathrm{P} 1}\left(\left|\psi_{2}^{*}\right\rangle\left\langle\psi_{2}^{*}\right|\right)=\sum_{m=0}^{n} \sum_{h \in H_{m}}\left(\sum_{k=0}^{\left\lvert\, \frac{2^{n}-1}{2}\right.} w_{\ell}(k) b_{n, m}\left(t_{\ell}^{\prime}(k)\right)\right) \cdot\left|V^{*}(h)\right\rangle_{\mathrm{Ut}}\left\langle V^{*}(h)\right|_{\mathrm{Ut}}
$$

By Definition 10, this is equal to,

$$
\sum_{m=0}^{n} \sum_{h \in H_{m}}\left(\gamma(n, m)+u_{\ell}(n, m)\right)\left|V^{*}(h)\right\rangle_{\mathrm{Ut}}\left\langle V^{*}(h)\right|_{\mathrm{Ut}}
$$

We are interested in the expected value of the Ut register, which is equal to,

$$
\left\langle\psi_{2}^{*}\right|\left(I^{\otimes \ell+n} \otimes|1\rangle\langle 1|\right)\left|\psi_{2}^{*}\right\rangle=\sum_{m=0}^{n} \sum_{h \in H_{m}}\left(\gamma(n, m)+u_{\ell}(n, m)\right)\left\langle V^{*}(h) \mid 1\right\rangle\langle 1| V^{*}(h)\rangle
$$

By Equation (35), this is equivalent to,

$$
\sum_{m=0}^{n} \sum_{h \in H_{m}}\left(\gamma(n, m)+u_{\ell}(n, m)\right)\left(\hat{V}^{*}(h)+\delta_{h}^{*}\right)
$$

Subtracting our estimates for $\Phi_{i}^{-}$from $\Phi_{i}^{+}$and multiplying by $V_{\max }-V_{\min }$ results in,

$$
\left(V_{\max }-V_{\min }\right)\left(\sum_{m=0}^{n} \sum_{h \in H_{m}}\left(\gamma(n, m)+u_{\ell}(n, m)\right)\left(\left(\hat{V}^{*}(h)-\hat{V}^{-}(h)\right)+\delta_{h}\right)\right)
$$

Multiplying the terms out yields,

$$
\Phi_{i}+\left(V_{\max }-V_{\min }\right)\left(\sum_{m=0}^{n} \sum_{h \in H_{m}}\left[\gamma(n, m) \delta_{h}\right]+\sum_{m=0}^{n} \sum_{h \in H_{m}}\left[u_{\ell}(n, m)\left(\hat{V}^{*}(h)-\hat{V}^{-}(h)\right)\right]+\sum_{m=0}^{n} \sum_{h \in H_{m}}\left[u_{\ell}(n, m) \delta_{h}\right]\right)
$$

Thus, we have three error terms, and we now find an absolute bound for each of them. The first term can be bounded easily, using Lemma 1 and Equation (35), we have the following,

$$
\left|\sum_{m=0}^{n} \sum_{h \in H_{m}} \gamma(n, m) \delta_{h}\right| \leq \sum_{m=0}^{n} \sum_{h \in H_{m}} \gamma(n, m)\left|\delta_{h}\right| \leq \delta_{\max } \sum_{m=0}^{n} \sum_{h \in H_{m}} \gamma(n, m)=\delta_{\max }
$$

The second term is calculated in Theorem 7. In particular, noting that we have $\hat{V}^{*}(h) \in[0,1]$,

$$
\left|\sum_{m=0}^{n} \sum_{h \in H_{m}} u_{\ell}(n, m)\left(\hat{V}^{+}(h)-\hat{V}^{-}(h)\right)\right| \leq \frac{\sqrt{n}}{2^{\ell-3}}
$$

Finally, we have the error introduced by the third term. By an almost identical calculation to that in Theorem 7, we find that,

$$
\left|\sum_{m=0}^{n} \sum_{h \in H_{m}} u_{\ell}(n, m) \delta_{h}\right| \leq \frac{\delta_{\max } \sqrt{n}}{2^{\ell-3}}
$$

Thus, the combined error introduced from Steps 1 and 2 is bounded by:

$$
\left(V_{\max }-V_{\min }\right) \cdot\left(\frac{\sqrt{n}}{2^{\ell-3}} \delta_{\max }+\frac{\sqrt{n}}{2^{\ell-3}}+\delta_{\max }\right)
$$

Note that, no matter how large we make $\ell$, the error persists if we are unable to also minimize $\delta_{\max }$.
D. 3 Error - Step 3. For this step, we use a quantum subroutine for speeding up Monte Carlo Methods [22]. With a probability greater than $8 / \pi^{2}$, the procedure succeeds. The process can be repeated $\mathcal{O}(\log (1 / p))$ times to improve the success probability to $1-p$. Suppose we perform $t$ iterations of amplitude estimation. If we are trying to extract value $\mu$, and the result is $\hat{\mu}$, the error is bounded,

$$
|\hat{\mu}-\mu| \leq 2 \pi \frac{\sqrt{\mu(1-\mu)}}{t}+\frac{\pi^{2}}{t^{2}}
$$

In our case, $\mu=\left(\Phi_{i}-V_{\min }\right) /\left(V_{\max }-V_{\min }\right) \in[0,1]$, so we can take the following more simple upper bound,

$$
|\hat{\mu}-\mu| \leq 2 \pi \frac{t \sqrt{\mu}+\pi}{t^{2}}
$$

Since we are extracting the value $\mu=\left(V_{\max }-V_{\min }\right)\left(\left.\psi_{2}\right|\left(I^{\otimes \ell+n} \otimes|1\rangle\langle 1|\right)\left|\psi_{2}\right\rangle\right.$, our final error is,

$$
\left(V_{\max }-V_{\min }\right)\left(\frac{\sqrt{n}}{2^{\ell-3}} \delta_{\max }+\frac{\sqrt{n}}{2^{\ell-3}}+\delta_{\max }+2 \pi \frac{t \sqrt{\mu}+\pi}{t^{2}}\right)
$$

D. 4 Complexity. Suppose we want a total error of $\epsilon$. This section finds an upper bound of complexity given a desired error. Let $\sqrt{n} / 2^{\ell-3}, \delta_{\max }, 2 \pi(t \sqrt{\mu}+\pi) / t^{2} \leq \epsilon^{\prime}$ be less than or equal to 1 , then the error is bounded by,

$$
\left(V_{\max }-V_{\min }\right)\left(\left(\epsilon^{\prime}\right)^{2}+3 \epsilon^{\prime}\right) \leq 4\left(V_{\max }-V_{\min }\right) \epsilon^{\prime}
$$

Hence, an upper bound of error $\epsilon$ can be achieved if, $\epsilon^{\prime} \leq \epsilon /\left(4\left(V_{\max }-V_{\min }\right)\right)$.
For notational simplicity, we define,

$$
\lambda=\frac{V_{\max }-V_{\min }}{\epsilon}
$$

to get $\sqrt{n} / 2^{\ell-3}$ less than $\epsilon^{\prime}$, a partition register of size,

$$
\ell=\left\lceil\log _{2}(\lambda \sqrt{n})\right\rceil+5
$$

is sufficient.
Recall $C_{D}(\ell)$ to be the complexity of implementing $D_{\ell}$ (cf. Definition 8) with an error with respect to $w_{\ell}(k)$ of less than $4^{-\ell}, \delta_{\max }$ on the other hand depends on the complexity of computing $U_{V}^{ \pm}$with max error $\epsilon^{\prime}$, which we write $C_{V}\left(\epsilon^{\prime}\right)$.

Definition 12. We denote the complexity to implement $U_{V}^{ \pm}$, such that the maximum error $\delta_{\max }$ (Equations (35) and (36)) is upper bounded by $\epsilon^{\prime}$, as $C_{V}\left(\epsilon^{\prime}\right)$.

Additionally, to sufficiently bound the error introduced by Step 3, we must satisfy $2 \pi(t \sqrt{\mu}+\pi) / t^{2} \leq \epsilon /\left(4\left(V_{\max }-V_{\min }\right)\right)$. Suppose that we wish our absolute error $\epsilon$ to be less than the difference $\Phi_{i}-V_{\min }$. Using the quadratic formula, we see

it is sufficient to take $t$ equal to,

$$
t=\left|\frac{28 \sqrt{\left(\Phi_{t}-V_{\min }\right)\left(V_{\max }-V_{\min }\right)}}{\epsilon}\right|
$$

Finally, with the upper bounds for these important factors in mind, let us consider the complexity in terms of CNOT gates given these upper bounds. Generating $\left|\psi_{1 a}\right\rangle$ is complexity $C_{D}(\ell)$. Next, evolving to $\left|\psi_{1 b}\right\rangle$ takes $n \ell$ controlled rotations, which can be implemented with $2 n \ell$ CNOTs in $2 \cdot \max (n, \ell)$ layers. From here, producing state $\left|\psi_{2}\right\rangle$ has complexity $C_{V}\left(4^{-1} \lambda^{-1}\right)$. Next, Step 3 involves amplitude estimation, meaning the above steps are repeated $t$ times, followed by an Inverse Quantum Fourier Transform on $\log _{2}(t)$ bits taking $O\left(\log _{2}^{2} t\right)$ operation. Hence, the total complexity is bounded by,

$$
t \cdot\left(C_{D}(\ell)+2 n \ell+C_{V}\left(\frac{1}{4 \lambda}\right)\right)+O\left(\log ^{2} t\right)
$$

where $\lambda$ is defined in Equation (38), and conservative values for $\ell$ and $t$ are given in Equations (39) and 40 respectively.
Theorem 8. Suppose there exists a constant real positive number $b$ such that $C_{V}(a \epsilon)>(b / a) C_{V}(\epsilon)$ for all real positive a. The total complexity of the algorithm is,

$$
O\left(\frac{\sqrt{\left(\Phi_{t}-V_{\min }\right)\left(V_{\max }-V_{\min }\right)}}{\epsilon}\left(C_{D}\left(\log _{2}(\lambda \sqrt{n})\right)+n \log _{2}(\lambda \sqrt{n})+C_{V}\left(\frac{1}{4 \lambda}\right)\right)\right)
$$

Proof. The result follows directly from Equation (41).

abstract:
This work focuses on developing efficient post-hoc explanations for quantum
AI algorithms. In classical contexts, the cooperative game theory concept of
the Shapley value adapts naturally to post-hoc explanations, where it can be
used to identify which factors are important in an AI's decision-making
process. An interesting question is how to translate Shapley values to the
quantum setting and whether quantum effects could be used to accelerate their
calculation. We propose quantum algorithms that can extract Shapley values
within some confidence interval. Our method is capable of quadratically
outperforming classical Monte Carlo approaches to approximating Shapley values
up to polylogarithmic factors in various circumstances. We demonstrate the
validity of our approach empirically with specific voting games and provide
rigorous proofs of performance for general cooperative games.
